Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SCIF1004 - Science and the Cinema","description":"

Can you imagine Dennis Quaid, Uma Thurman, Sam Neill or Kate Winslet as scientists? Well Hollywood has, in a series of movies which use real scientific concepts as an integral part of the plot. Often the script writers stretch these concepts beyond the realms of reality to make the movies even more exciting. In this general education online elective you will view a series of movies which deal with a range of scientific issues with accompanying lectures to help you understand the concepts.


Movies you will watch include Gattaca (starring Ethan Hawke, Jude Law and Uma Thurman), Jurassic Park (Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum and Laura Dern), The Day After Tomorrow (Dennis Quaid, Jake Gyllenhaal and Emmy Rossum) and more. So enroll, see some movies and you might learn enough science to create your own genetically modified organism, alternative source of energy, deep space exploration vehicle or help save the world from a cataclysmic disaster.


This course is delivered purely online!

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d6d5c533db791c50eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Piece","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students must write a discussion piece (min. 900 words, max. 1000) on how a science/scientific concept has been portrayed in film, they may use films from the course or others of their own choosing. If they choose a film that is not part of this course then it is made clear that it is a good idea to contact the course coordinator to see if their film is suitable (as a common issue when selecting their own film is that the science involved is not actually science and instead is merely a bunch of made up terms used as a plot device). The piece is not supposed to be an attack on a series of films, highlighting the absurdity of what transpires. Films and additional material (background research) is to be referenced correctly.

Submissions will be via Moodle and will be marked by postgraduate students. The final mark will be provided via Moodle using a rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ad5c533db791c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d6d5c533db791c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ed5c533db791c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes on lectures and movies","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

There will be a series of quizzes (one per movie and/or lecture). These will be taken online (via Moodle) once the student has viewed the lecture/movie. These questions are designed to see if students paid attention to and thought about the science which is occurring in the film as they watch it. Scores will be returned to the students instantly once they submit their completed quiz attempt.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ad5c533db791c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"46d58533db791c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Free-Form Piece","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The Free-Form Piece is a students chance to not only showcase their creativity but allows them to amalgamate all that they have learnt during their time studying on this course. For this assignment students have to submit ‘a body of work’ that comes under the general headline ‘Science and the Cinema’. It is up to them to use the knowledge that they have gained on this course with their own unique skill set to create a submission that addresses the topic. Now there are a great many of ways to address this rather general headline, a list of some suggestions is provided and explar work form previous years is given, again, students can contact the coordinator before they start to see if their ideas are suitable.

The assessment item will be submitted via Moodle and marked by postgraduate students. The final mark will be provided via a rubric on Moodle.

Perspectives in Medical Science","description":"

SCIF1111 introduces students to the skills required by a professional in medical research. The course gives students the opportunity to practise these skills and identify those which may need improvement through their academic career.


The historical and philosophical component of the course provides students with a foundation and origin of current research and practice.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"597c4796dbb8e81055a93324f3961962","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will prepare and present a seminar on an aspect of Medical Science of their choice.

A preliminary written proposal will be used as formative assessment to give the studentsan opportunity to curate thier references and provide feedback on their topic.

The presentation will be tutor and peer marked using a rubric devised by student input.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"117c4796dbb8e81055a93324f39619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"997c4796dbb8e81055a93324f3961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"917c4796dbb8e81055a93324f39619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"E-portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Each student will create an e-portfolio outlining the work progress of the final History of Medical Science project, drawing together concepts learnt in the graduate attribute stream and the research in the discipline streams, showing evidence of the students’ development as a professional in their field. It will consist of many parts, contributed throughout the term: individual research for the project, evidence of contribution to the project, reflections on their experience within the project of teamwork, critical and creative thinking and ethics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"117c4796dbb8e81055a93324f39619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"197c4796dbb8e81055a93324f39619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"917c4796dbb8e81055a93324f3961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"997c4796dbb8e81055a93324f3961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d17c4796dbb8e81055a93324f39619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"History of Medical Science Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This project will give the students to the history of a piece of medical technology or disease, concentrating on its impact on humans throughout time. This will be a team project and presented as a poster, video (or presentation) in the last week of term during HPS face-to-face class.

contentlets.description:
SCIF1111 introduces students to the skills required by a professional in medical research. The course gives students the opportunity to practise these skills and identify those which may need improvement through their academic career.

The historical and philosophical component of the course provides students with a foundation and origin of current research and practice.

Introductory Skills for Science","description":"

SCIF1131 provides the opportunity for students to become aware of and develop their professional capabilities. As few great ideas are created in isolation, the connection between like-minded individuals, as well as building on past and present ideas, are the foundation for innovation. Development of these ideas requires collaboration (fitting different pieces together and critical appraisal) and communication for wider awareness. In this course, students will practise teamwork and communication, both as generic skills and within a scientific discipline.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"006cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961993","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will prepare information on a topic of their choice, and present this in class.

This task will include:

  • 15% for the preparation of a written proposal, which will be fully referenced and peer reviewed in class (plus the peer review process will be worth 5%)
  • 15% for the presentation in-class (plus the peer review of each presentation will be worth 5%)

Presentation rubric will be devised as a result of class discussion and student input.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c46cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c46cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c86cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc6cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"006cc396dbb8e81055a93324f39619d7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Formative e-portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Each student will create an e-portfolio outlining the work progress of their discipline-based project. This draws together concepts learnt in the graduate attribute stream and the research in the discipline streams, showing evidence of the students’ development as a professional in their field. It will consist of many parts, contributed throughout the term: individual research for the project, evidence of contribution to the project, reflections on their experience within the project of teamwork, critical and creative thinking and ethics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c46cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c46cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c86cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cc6cc396dbb8e81055a93324f3961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"186cc396dbb8e81055a93324f39619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final project/poster","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

In groups within each discipline stream, the students will produce a poster on a topic devised by the teams and under the guidance of an academic supervisor from the participating schools.

An additional individual component involving peer team evaluation will be worth 5%.

Marking of these final assessments will be both peer review and staff. A rubric will be devised based on the Research Skills development framework (https://www.adelaide.edu.au/rsd/).

Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff. The internship may encompass project planning, literature review, project development, fieldwork, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written reporting. Internships may also involve a placements outside of UNSW, in the form of externally funded research programs. In these cases students will require an academic member of staff to supervise the internship.


Note: Enrolment in this course is by application, and subject to availability of places. Interested students should have identified a potential supervisor and research placement prior to applying.


To apply, download the form from the Science website and submit it to the Science Student Centre.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SCIF3000 - Science Industry Project","description":"

This course provides an opportunity for science students to apply and contextualise their disciplinary knowledge and transferrable skills on real-world science projects, offered by a partner organisation within industry, government or the not-for-profit sectors. Under the guidance of academic supervisors and workplace mentors, students will work collaboratively in multidisciplinary science teams to deliver an outcome for an external client. The course enables students to develop teamwork, project management and problem-solving skills in a professional context and enhance their employability through experiential learning and engagement with authentic, meaningful work.


The course is available to domestic and international students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c84ade2bdbe07850fe4b322af49619de","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Final Report/Deliverable","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Group Assessment. 

This is a report of 3000 words, or equivalent project deliverable/output for the partner organisation. It will include an outline of the project and background, solution and outcomes, lessons learnt and possible cautions, and other relevant supporting materials.

Students will receive formative feedback prior to the Final Presentation Assessment.

Due Week 9.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b6ad66bdbe07850fe4b322af4961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"be0b9eebdbe07850fe4b322af49619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"de9a52abdbe07850fe4b322af4961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f6fa9aebdbe07850fe4b322af4961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"301e9e63db247850fe4b322af496197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Individual assessment

Part a) 4x 2-minute video or 250-word submission throughout the project engagement (Due in weeks 2, 4, 6, 8). Worth 10%

Part b) 1,000 word essay due during examination period (10%)

Further details:

Students will log a series of 4 reflections (one per fortnight), reflecting on their personal and professional development, with a focus on client interaction, teamwork and project management. Students will receive feedback on these reflections throughout the course.

The final reflection essay will require students to reflect on the WIL experience after the project engagement has concluded. Students will revisit previous reflection submissions and comment on their progress and development throughout the engagement. Students will also consider peer review feedback from fellow team members and the feedback of industry mentors and academic supervisors to reflect on strengths and limitations, and what they might need to do to improve capabilities in the future.

Students will develop a 1000-word Project Plan for their WIL project, including a team charter. Students will outline:

- background to the project

- project aims and rationale 

- steps, milestones and timeline to complete the project

- team roles, responsibilities and communication strategy

- expected outcomes and outputs

- concerns and possible approaches to address stated concerns

 

 

Due Week 3.

The course is available to domestic and international students.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SCIF3199 - Science Work Placement","description":"
 

This course has been developed for students who find a work placement/internship (unpaid or paid) and would like to receive academic credit for the placement. 


This course will enable students to explore and gain a practical understanding of the requirements and expectations of the professional workplace through experiential learning. Students will develop their knowledge, capabilities and employability skills. Internships/work placements enable students to gain practical, supervised experience in the work place.


The course is available to domestic and international students. If a domestic or international student wishes to undertake an overseas work placement, extra conditions will apply before the placement is approved.


In order to receive SCIF3199 credit for their work placement, students must have approval BEFORE their placement starts.


Permission to enrol in SCIF3199 will only be granted if the work internship/work placement is compatible to the student's major. Students who wish to enrol must have successfully completed a minimum of 48 UoC and have a WAM of >65 with no more than 1 fail. Students who have declared a Psychology major, or are enrolled in a Psychology or Vision Science program are not permitted to enrol in SCIF3199.


Placements are to be a minimum of 3 weeks full-time (105 hours or more). This may be done intensively in the term break or spread out over the term as approximately 11 hours per week.


SCIF3199 will count as a Science elective and is non-graded - this course is satisfactory/unsatisfactory.


Note: For details on how to apply for SCIF3199, please go to https://www.science.unsw.edu.au/student-life/student-opportunities/work-placement/science-work-placement-course https://www.science.unsw.edu.au/student-life/student-opportunities/work-placements

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"831944fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619ad","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Workshop tasks","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The workshops will be synchronous and involve some preparation and group discussion. Each will have an associated task, which will be completed individually and contribute to the assessment mark. Workshop assessments will ideally take place in Weeks 1-4 as they are meant to give the students knowledge, confidence and skills prior to the placement, but this may change depending on when students are able to attend the workshops.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"571984fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f1984fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Supervisor report","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The student's workplace supervisor will be provided with a report template to be completed on the completion of the placement. This include questions about the student's technical and professional competencies. The supervisor report is submitted to course convener after the placement which will then be given to the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"531984fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5f1984fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"931984fbdbe31050358b403c3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Work placement e-portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The students will complete a series of ten reflections (one per week) evaluating their performance and professional growth while on placement. Feedback will be on-going and check-ins will take place with the convener throughout the placement.

This course offers an introduction to concepts and tools necessary for understanding the challenges of sustainable development in the transport-environment-tourism nexus. Students will develop skills in comprehending and assessing the environmental, social and economic sustainability of societal decisions in the context of tourism. A field excursion to Lady Elliott Island – located in the Southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef - will be undertaken with the objective of allowing students to develop an understanding of these societal trade-offs. The field-based learning will emphasise teamwork, as well as independent observational and enquiry skills using remote eco-resort as a context. Topics will include issues at the interface of transport and tourism management and sustainable development principles. Students will engage in preparatory learning leading up to the excursion, as well as reflective learning through assignments during- and post-trip. Around 24 hours of class, including education tours, fieldwork and presentations, are delivered on the island during the field excursion. This is a summer intensive course. Students should be aware that additional costs associated with the field trip will be incurred including return airfare to Lady Elliott Island (LEI), accommodation and food. This course is also available as AVIA3900.

All theoretical and empirical work in the course will be assessable. The take-home exam will be a mix of short-answer questions and essays.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"135001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2b5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"135001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be allocated scientific papers on sustainable tourism management. Each student will be required to submit summaries of the scientific papers. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"135001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"275001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2b5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"675001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field based assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete a collection of tasks during the field excursion such as mapping and writing field notes. Field notes will involve activities such as observing and finding information about the challenges and solutions in operational and logistic management, waste management, and general sustainable destination management practices in the context of a remote tourism resort. Mapping tasks will involve identifying and drawing key geographical characteristics such as land forms, vegetation, as well as evidence of human-impact. Students will also be assessed on the fundamentals of map presentation. For the field assignments, the focus will be on developing the capacity to undertake independent observation and enquiry skills. A predetermined criteria will be used for instructors and peers.

This course introduces you to how science is communicated in a range of settings, to a range of audiences and in a range of formats. You will examine key frameworks and methods of communication and apply them to effectively communicate and represent science in various contexts.  You will also learn how to evaluate science communication efforts and analyse the data.  Learning activities and assessments will be integrated through case studies featuring models of science communication and strategies for creating effective pieces of communication in line with the themes of the case studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"09be469adbc66810eb6b147a3a96191a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to produce a 250 word reflection on ways in which their learning informs and advances their becoming an effective, creative, ethical and responsible scientific communicator in the digital and changing world

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cdbe469adbc66810eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"41be469adbc66810eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Piece of Science Communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This is a negotiable assessment task, students can choose to write an essay on a scientific topic, a research paper, a grant application or an analysis and improvement of an assignment in another course in the program applying the principles of design features and models of effective science communication.

Students will receive written feedback on their recorded presentation together with a class general feedback two weeks after marks have been finalised.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c1be469adbc66810eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c9be469adbc66810eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"41be469adbc66810eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a negotiable assessment task, students can choose to present a public talk, a one-side debate on a scientific phenomenon such as climate change, a school visit talk, a conference presentation on a science topic of their choice.

Students will receive written feedback on their recorded presentation together with a class general feedback two weeks after marks have been finalised.

Students will receive written feedback on their returned assignment together with a class general feedback two weeks after marks have been finalised.

contentlets.description: This course introduces you to how science is communicated in a range of settings, to a range of audiences and in a range of formats. You will examine key frameworks and methods of communication and apply them to effectively communicate and represent science in various contexts.  You will also learn how to evaluate science communication efforts and analyse the data.  Learning activities and assessments will be integrated through case studies featuring models of science communication and strategies for creating effective pieces of communication in line with the themes of the case studies.
contentlets.title: Advanced Communication Skills in Science

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SCIF7010 - Leading Science for Impact","description":"

Leading Science for Impact is designed for professionals who seek to influence and lead social and environmental change using science. Grounded in scientific thinking, social impact methods and decision making, this course aims to equip students with essential knowledge and practical skills to create positive change to enhance social and environmental sustainability.  You will learn about how different forms of knowledge are used to inform change, ethical questions that emerge in knowledge translation and social change, local and global trends impacting science in society, policy processes and decision making. In addition, students will develop their knowledge of the how achieve political and social influence.  In doing so, they will gain practical skills in translating research and, where appropriate, commercialisation. Learning activities will link to real-life contexts and support your professional development.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c4efc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective piece","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to reflect on their engagement with their Leading science for impact initiative, their learning in the course, and how to use their learning for their future development.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4cefc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3bdfc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussion Forums","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to participate actively in the weekly Discussion Forums. Participation might include discussion of key concepts and their applications in real-world contexts, review and analysis of course learning materials, and reflection.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"00efc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3fdfc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"48efc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4cefc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"84efc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c0efc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ffdfc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7dfc5bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Leading science for impact initiative","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment comprises three connected parts: Part A is an issue analysis (800 words, 20%, due in Wk 5), Part B is a written report of the initiative (1,700 words + diagrams graphics, 30%, due in Wk10).

Part A requires students to choose a current issue that requires a positive change to enhance social and environmental sustainability. They will argue for its significance, analyse the factors that impact on the issue such as socio-cultural, economic, political, ethical or environmental factors; and discuss how to address the issue so that a positive change can be made for social and environmental impact.

Part B requires students to use the feedback to improve the analysis of the issue and develop a science for impact initiative to address the issue. They will also provide a proposal for the implementation and evaluation of the initiative.

This course deals with the foundational knowledge about scientific research methods and statistics in scientific professional practice. It aims to enable science professionals to develop systematic, critical and analytical scientific thinking to engage with research and draw on the research literature to inform their practice. You will learn to perform basic statistical analysis procedures, draw defensible conclusions and assess the validity of conclusions based on statistical analysis of experimental data. You will be able to develop your critical thinking through examining the design and execution of experiments, critiquing the analysis and interpretation of results, scrutinising and evaluating published research, and discriminating between evidence-based information and pseudoscience.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b0ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961964","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes. These quizzes will be held weekly during weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the lectures and readings in the previous week. Each quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions. The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b8ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f4ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f8ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data analysis and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to participate in an online experiment designed to elicit data for this assessment and to analyse the data obtained from all students. In the report (2000 words) they will have to describe the experimental procedure and data analysis method, present the results of their analysis and interpret the results within an appropriate theoretical framework and in the light of previous research. The research report is due Sunday Week 10.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle 10 working days from the due date. Assessment submitted after this date will not be marked and receive a mark of zero. Alternative assessment arrangement will be made for students with approved special consideration.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b8ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f4ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a8ef09bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96193d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Article critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be given an article reporting a study. Through open ended questions they will be required to critique the methodology used in the study including the research question and hypothesis, experimental design, independent and dependent variables and confounding variables. The critique will be approximately 750 words and due Sunday of Week 4. Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday of Week 6. Assessment submitted after this time will not be marked and will receive a mark of zero. Alternative assessment arrangement will be made for students with approved special consideration.

contentlets.keywords: faculty of science,critical thinking,statistics in science,evidence-based practice,informed decision making,pseudoscience
contentlets.description: This course deals with the foundational knowledge about scientific research methods and statistics in scientific professional practice. It aims to enable science professionals to develop systematic, critical and analytical scientific thinking to engage with research and draw on the research literature to inform their practice. You will learn to perform basic statistical analysis procedures, draw defensible conclusions and assess the validity of conclusions based on statistical analysis of experimental data. You will be able to develop your critical thinking through examining the design and execution of experiments, critiquing the analysis and interpretation of results, scrutinising and evaluating published research, and discriminating between evidence-based information and pseudoscience.
contentlets.title: Critical Thinking in Scientific Practice

This course aims to provide students with theories and best practice models to support them in becoming a global scientist and an equitable leader. You will learn about globalisation and scientific contributions to sustainable global development and active global engagement. You will also learn about principles underpinning equity, diversity and inclusion in a local and global science context and apply them to foster an equitable and inclusive work environment through policies and organisational practice. Learning activities and assessments will be integrated through case studies and real-world scenarios which feature theories, strategies and reflections for equitable and inclusive leadership and practice. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4fef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Learning Activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Quizzes, discussion board, responses and/or reflections depending on the topic of the week.  (20% - 2% x 10 weekly)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0fef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4bef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"87ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c3ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3eef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students select one goal from United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and discuss ways in which science in general or the sub-discipline of science (students’ primary expertise) contributes to achieving this goal globally and locally. In the essay, students are required to examine opportunities and challenges arising from diverse cultures, world political geography behaviours and the national socio-economic situations, and explore how to move towards achieving sustainable global development. Students will then take these strategies to a local community and explore how to enable sustainable and equitable global engagement in the community context from a science perspective.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0fef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4bef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"87ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Students choose one science-related company and use the principles of equity, diversity and inclusion to examine the company’s relevant policies and operational practices. They will be asked to critically examine how equity values are addressed, how these policies work in theory and in practice, and identify key equity and diversity risks and opportunities for the company.

\n

Based on their examination, they will evaluate the extent to which these policies and practices contribute to creating positive outcomes and a positive working environment and make suitable recommendations for improvement. They will also be required to reflect on their learning in the course and articulate how their learning has informed their development of cultural, social, ethical and professional competence and ways to ensure equitable and inclusive practice locally and globally.

This course introduces you to the knowledge and skills required for leading and contributing to a project from inception to successful completion in a STEM context. You will learn about the life cycle of a scientific project and identify opportunities and challenges impacting on the decision marking, management and performance. You will also learn to use suitable tools, strategies and processes to articulate a structured and collaborative approach with which to plan, organise, monitor and deliver a scientific project. You will be enabled to develop project management competencies including scope, time, cost, quality, resource, risk, communication and integration management. This course emphasises experiential learning in that you will work with your peers applying your learning on a real-world scientific project and learning from reflections.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"71b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Project proposal is the second assessment item. Each group will submit their project proposal- 1200 words in Week 5.  They are required to identify and discuss: a, project outcomes; b, relevant stakeholders; c, milestones and activities, timelines, register of stakeholders, roles and responsibilities of team members; d, budgets for all required project resources (including human resources); e, significant risks and risk management.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6db0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a9b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

This assessment is negotiable. As individuals, students can submit either a milestone report, grant application for a child project, a business case to further the project or a pitch talk. Written work is 1500 words and oral presentation is 30 minutes together with written material complimenting the presentation. This assessment is due in Week 10.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6db0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a9b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are required to keep a reflective journal throughout the course and submit it for assessment in Week 10. They will be required to reflect on: a) their team role playing, teamwork contribution and teamwork processes; b)  learning from the course; and c) own development of project management competencies.

Feedback will be provided on the returned work, together with the marking rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6db0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a9b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69b0e9b7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Memo","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be working in groups of between 5 to 7 members on a real-world project sourced from external industry partners and UNSW Alumni. Depending on the availability of projects, they will work on their own project or the same project for the whole class. At the start of the project, students use Belbin team Inventory test to assign roles to the conduct of the project. Midway through the term, they will swap their roles. As they collaborate on the projects, they are required to produce work for assessment as both individual and group work.

The Project Memo is the first assessment item where students will deliver a 10 minute presentation as a group to their clients who provide the project and their peers who act as industry audience and reviewers. They will be required to define the project outcomes, scope the work that needs to be accomplished to deliver the outcomes and assess the team’s strengths and weaknesses in delivering the outcomes. This assessment item is due in Week 3.

Feedback will be provided by other teams in the class using a Peer review checklist and from the course convenor using the marking rubric. Depending on negotiation with external industry partners and UNSW Alumni, the clients may be able to provide inputs to the construction of the marking rubric and provision of feedback.

contentlets.keywords: faculty of science,project management,scientific project management,stem project management,management
contentlets.description: This course introduces you to the knowledge and skills required for leading and contributing to a project from inception to successful completion in a STEM context. You will learn about the life cycle of a scientific project and identify opportunities and challenges impacting on the decision marking, management and performance. You will also learn to use suitable tools, strategies and processes to articulate a structured and collaborative approach with which to plan, organise, monitor and deliver a scientific project. You will be enabled to develop project management competencies including scope, time, cost, quality, resource, risk, communication and integration management. This course emphasises experiential learning in that you will work with your peers applying your learning on a real-world scientific project and learning from reflections.
contentlets.title: Scientific Project Management

This capstone professional experience project is designed to be undertaken in your own workplace. In this course you will identify an issue arising in your workplace that compromises the quality of the practice or an aspect of the practice that would benefit from improvement. You will then research for strategies to tackle the issue and/or improve the practice and assess these strategies in a relevant professional context using a recognised framework or a self-created framework informed by the relevant literature. Based on your assessment, you will design an innovation, implement the innovation, evaluate the effectiveness and efficacy of the innovation in the professional practice context and report on the innovation. As a requirement of this course, you will nominate a colleague who will act as a critical friend to provide you with feedback and support during your innovation project. This course aims to integrate your leadership capabilities, professional skills and technical expertise in designing, implementing and evaluating innovations for enhancement of professional practice.

Note: Students should enrol in this course over two consecutive terms for a total of 12UoC.

This capstone professional experience project focuses on applied research and is linked with external agencies, industries and businesses who provide real-world projects to teams of students to work on. The projects will present a real-world problem and require you to collaborate in your team to solve it virtually, in an online learning environment. This course will enable you to integrate your leadership capabilities, professional skills and technical expertise into a meaningful experience that will consolidate and extend your learning in the program. External industry partners and UNSW Alumni will act as critical friends to provide you with feedback during your project. They will contribute expertise as part of your online learning community both synchronously and asynchronously.

Note: Students should enrol in this course over two consecutive terms for a total of 12UoC

contentlets.keywords: faculty of science,capstone,work integrated learning,innovation,industry-led project,applied research
contentlets.description:
This capstone professional experience project focuses on applied research and is linked with external agencies, industries and businesses who provide real-world projects to teams of students to work on. The projects will present a real-world problem and require you to collaborate in your team to solve it virtually, in an online learning environment. This course will enable you to integrate your leadership capabilities, professional skills and technical expertise into a meaningful experience that will consolidate and extend your learning in the program. External industry partners and UNSW Alumni will act as critical friends to provide you with feedback during your project. They will contribute expertise as part of your online learning community both synchronously and asynchronously.

Note: Students should enrol in this course over two consecutive terms for a total of 12UoC
